instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V_G3H_RTC? PP3V_G3H_RTC is a 3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state that powers the RTC circuit. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
I'm working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A which came with liquid damage - primary as a data recovery job.
I cleaned the liquid damaged areas. The logicboard pulses 63-64mA.
<CAPACITOR>C6404</CAPACITOR> Pin2 is completely gone so i took the cap away - i think it's not necessary for data recovery?

The board shows no reaction. Here are my measurements ...

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12,600V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,307V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1,804V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1,804V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1,102V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0,798V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 3.306V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1,199V
<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,299V
<SIGNAL>P3V3MAIN_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 3,274V
<SIGNAL>PP3V_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3,007V
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3,007V
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,304 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 5,128V

Then i wanted to check DFU (i have not much experience with this).
Normaly i would expect to see the DFU - Logo on the Display of the machine with Apple Configurator2.
But it shows me a Logo with REVOVERY. This Logo comes without pressing any Key-combination, only after plug in the data-cable (usb-c to usb-c). What does this mean? What is the difference between DFU and RECOVERY? 
All functions i tried to use didn't work (restart, repair, shutdown, backup etc.)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
Did you note liquid signs on J6600 connector/flex, or Touch ID?

Do you get any S5, or S3 voltage on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
It looks like there is no S3 S5 voltage on the board ...

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVPCORE_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>PP1V_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V

On J6600 connector/flex and Touch ID i can't find any signs of liquid

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
Did you try to enter DFU as in the tutorial?
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
I did it again: In the moment i plugin the usb-c cable between the two machines the Apple Configurator2 shows the Logo with RECOVERY (without pressing any key).

without paying any attention to that, I used the key combination from the tutorial (Mr.Macintosh) - then the Logo changes from RECOVERY to DFU.

Is it normal that he runs automatically in this recovery-mode? What can i do now in the DFU-mode in AC2?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
I never saw this behavior yet.
Try first revive option; it will preserve SSD information.
If no luck, you may need to try restore; be aware, will erase SSD...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
The revive option brings an error ...
 (AMRestoreErrorDomain-Fehler 6 - Failed to handle message type StatusMsg (Operation failed)) [AMRestoreErrorDomain â€“ 0x6 (6)]

... restore kills the customer data.
Is there no other chance?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
Restore will probably fail, as revive too.
T2, or SSD problems, if DFU can't be done.

Just in case, check if is possible to start in Target Disk mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
Start in Target Disk mode don't work.
i don't have a lot of experience with ssd problems, can you give me some starting help for troubleshooting

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message: Did you take pictures with damaged areas, before cleaning?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
Here are pictures of the damaged areas - after cleaning with flux and heatgun. The filenames tell you the part/area. there are three pictures from <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> with a hole in the underfill material - is this from the production process or could this be an damage?

[ATTACH]60090[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60091[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60092[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60093[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60094[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60095[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60096[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60097[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60098[/ATTACH][ATTACH]60099[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message: If <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> got affected by liquid, T2 cannot properly access its SSD partition...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
ok so you think this underfill hole at <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> is from a damage and not from production?

What can i do next? Shall i get rid of the underfill and make a reflow or/and ultrasonic cleaning?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A DFU/RECOVERY
threads.message:
Your board has a damage caused by liquid more than sure; not 100% <CHIP>U8600</CHIP>, can be somewhere else.
You can try to heat all BGA chips with quality flux.
In case need to burn accumulated crap underneath.
If problem is <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> related, that explains why T2 cannot complete DFU.
